body_content.explanation: relating to a modern version of a style of building that was common between the 12th and 16th centuries and whose characteristics were pointed arches (= a structure, consisting of a curved top on two supports, that holds the weight of something above it) and windows, high ceilings, and tall, thin columns:
examples: The neo-Gothic design of the new library has divided public opinion.
The ornate neo-Gothic main school building dates from the 19th century.
